segment.tokens: that spiders ever mimic ants as a method of escaping from them
that some ants prey upon them
The foraging ants of South America destroy spiders many kinds of insects
Wallace mentions a small wood-boring ant
a small wood-boring ant fills its nest with small spiders
If the spiders deceive them by their mimicry
those would gain an advantage by a similar disguise
I once placed a little ant-like spider of the genus Herpyllus in a bottle with three ants no larger than itself , which I had caught with it in the sweep-net
three ants no larger than itself I had caught with it in the sweep-net
In a very few minutes the ants had killed
the ants begun to devour the spider
that the resemblance was sufficiently to deceive them in the open
when spider ants were confined together in close quarters
[ Illustration ] One morning Sir Bevis went down to the brook
then he picked a willow leaf
he threw it into the bubbles
it go whirling round round in the eddies
it back up under the fall , where it dived down and presently came up again
the stream carried it away past the flags
having now finished that part of his song
Bevis dear sit down in the shadow of the willow
I will tell you as much
The reed did not tell you the truth dear
indeed he does not know all
that I scarcely ever answer them now
they would keep on all day long
I should never hear the sound of my own voice
the sound of my own voice I like best
So I do not encourage them
I do not know myself always
Sometimes I sing about the sun , who loves me dearly
I tries all day to get at me through the leaves and the green flags that hide me
he does not like me to be in the shadow
Sometimes I sing to the wind , who loves me next most dearly , and will come to me everywhere in places where the sun can not get
the wind loves me next most dearly
the wind will come to me everywhere in places where the sun can not get
where the sun can not get
he has heard in the woods on the hills
He sends down the leaves to float along
for he knows I like something to carry
Fling me in some leaves , Bevis , dear
" Sometimes I sing to the earth and the grass
they are fond of me too
they listen the best of all
I sing loudest at night to the stars "
for they are so far away
they would not otherwise hear me
the brook was too occupied now to heed him
" Sometimes I sing to the trees
they too are fond of me
they would all come down to me
They love me like the rest
If I am broken to pieces against a stone
I do not mind in the least
I laugh just the same even louder
When I come over the hatch
sometimes a rainbow comes a little while with me
some of them hide in deep corners
they never have enough of me
the kingfisher is always with me
the kingfisher sits on the bough to see his ruddy breast in the water
you come too Bevis now then to listen to me "
